title: Functional in vitro and in vivo analysis of biosynthetic genes by heterologous expression in E. coli

Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Strain construction
Timing: 5 days
This step describes how the plasmids and strains for the heterologous expression of the biosynthetic gene cluster as well as for the expression of the His-tagged protein are constructed.
Perform PCRs of the Gibson assembly fragments.
Mix the components of the PCR reactions according to the table providing the PCR reaction master mix.
Note: Sequences of the primers can be found in the key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
table:files/protocols_protocol_2966_7.csv
Note: Primer JCK28_pRSF_duet_His.XA_Gib_rv binds to an already in pRSFDuett-1 included factor XA cutting site.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2966_8.csv
Calculate the correct extension time for the length of your fragment.
For Q5 polymerase use an extension time of 45 s per 1 kb for complex, GC-rich templates.
Run the PCR with the protocol outlined in the PCR cycling conditions table. (The table shows the extension time for darH in pJK6.1.)
table:files/protocols_protocol_2966_9.csv
Pause point: The PCR reaction can be stored overnight at 4°C prior to agarose gel electrophoresis and DNA purification.
Perform agarose gel electrophoresis for checking the PCR results.
Prepare a 1% agarose gel.
Place the gel tray in a gel caster to seal the edges of the gel tray and put a comb with an appropriate number of wells in the comb guide of the gel tray.
Weigh in 0.4 g agarose and suspend it in 40 mL 1× TAE buffer. Heat the suspension in a microwave to dissolve the agarose.
After the agarose is completely dissolved add 4 μL SYBR safe.
Pour the gel into the gel tray and let it polymerize for approx. 20 min.
Loading and running the gel.
Prepare the electrophoresis chamber by filling in 1× TAE buffer.
Place the gel in the electrophoresis chamber
Prepare a small strip of parafilm.

Take out 3 μL of 6× loading dye and divide it in two drops on the parafilm (one drop per PCR sample).
Use 3 μL of each PCR reaction and mix it with the loading dye drop on the parafilm (be careful to keep the drops separated) and load the mixture into the wells of the gel starting with the second well.
Add 10 μL of DNA Ladder into the first well and run the gel for 30 min at 120 V.
Analyze the gel under UV light.
PCR reactions yielding signals of the correct size (see Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]) can be purified by a PCR purification kit (troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2966-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Agarose gel of the PCR reactions for the construction of pJK6.1
Left: Agarose gel of the amplification of pZW-ADC9 with JCK7 and JCK8. A signal at the expected size of 5704 bp can be observed. The PCR reaction can be purified with a PCR purification kit and used for Gibson assembly. Right: Agarose gel of the PCR reaction of darH with JCK12 and JCK13. A signal at the expected size of 1555 bp can be detected. However, since there are other unspecific signals it is recommended to purify this signal from the gel before using it for a Gibson assembly.
Optional: After amplification of the plasmid backbone the sample can be treated with DpnI to get rid of template plasmid DNA to avoid false positives in the Gibson assembly.
Note: If the PCR shows unspecific signals (i.e., fragments not showing the desired size in the agarose gel analysis), it is more suitable to purify the desired fragment by cutting the correct signal from the gel.

Pause point: Unpurified PCR reactions can be stored at 4°C or −20°C until next day. Purified DNA should be stored at −20°C until further usage.
Perform a Gibson assembly using the PCR fragments (see Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
For 2–3 fragments use 0.02–0.5 pmol of DNA.
For calculating the required amount of the fragments use the following equation:   p m o l =  (  w e i g h t  i n  n g  )  ×  1000  (  b a s e  p a i r s × 650  d a l t i o n s  )     or the NEBioCalculator tool.7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7],8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]
Add the calculated volume of DNA to the Gibson assembly master mix4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4] and adjust the volume to 20 μL with ddH2O.
Incubate the mixture for 1 h at 50°C in a thermocycler.
Remove the salts from the assembled plasmid.
Fill a Petri dish (Ø94 mm) approx. three quarters with ultrapure water.
Place a MF-Millipore 0.025 μm MCE Membrane filter (13 mm) on the water surface.
Carefully pipette the Gibson assembly mixture on the filter and incubate it with closed lid for 1 h.
After incubation carefully transfer the Gibson assembly mixture into an Eppendorf tube.
Critical: When placing the membrane filter disk on the water do not touch it with your hands. Use a forceps to carefully take it from the packing and wear gloves.
Transform the assembled plasmid with E. coli Top10.
Thaw the competent cells on ice (when freshly prepared skip this step).
Add 5 μL of the salt free Gibson assembly mix from step 3b.
Transfer the mixture into an electroporation cuvette (0.2 cm gap) and make sure the liquid is at the bottom of the cuvette and free from air bubbles.

Place the cuvette in an electroporator (MicroPulser; Bio-Rad) and apply a voltage of 2.5 kV (bacteria Ec2). (A typical time constant is ∼5 ms.)
Immediately add 800 μL LB medium and mix gently by pipetting up and down.
Transfer the culture into a 2 mL Eppendorf tube and incubate for 1 h at 37°C.
After incubation centrifuge the culture for 4 min at 3000 × g.
Decant the supernatant until only approx. 200 μL are left.
Resuspend the cell pellet in the remainder of the supernatant and spread it on an LB agarose plate containing kanamycin.
Incubate the agar plate overnight at 37°C (troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Verify the correct assembly of the plasmid.
Pick colonies and plate them on a fresh LB agar plate containing kanamycin. Simultaneously, use the same colonies to inoculate 4 mL liquid LB medium containing kanamycin in a 15 mL falcon tube.
Mark fields on a Petri dish and number them. Add liquid LB agar containing kanamycin and allow the agar to solidify. Fill three 15 mL flacon tubes with 4 mL LB medium supplemented with kanamycin and number them from one to three.
Use an autoclaved toothpick to pick up one colony, streak it in field number 1 and transfer the toothpick into the liquid medium of falcon tube number one.
Repeat this step with two more colonies.
Plate 10 to 15 more colonies without inoculation in liquid medium in case you want to test more colonies later on.
Incubate the agar plate at 37°C and the liquid cultures at 180 rpm and 37°C overnight.
On the next day isolate the plasmids using a bacterial plasmid isolation kit and wrap the agar plate in parafilm for long-term storage at 4°C.
Pause point: Purified plasmids are stable for months if they are stored at −20°C.

Perform a restriction digest with the three isolated plasmids.
Choose a restriction enzyme that preferably has a cutting site in your plasmid and in the newly inserted fragment, for example EcoRI for pJK6.1 and SmaI for pJK9.1.
Measure the plasmid concentration with a NanoDrop.
Calculate the volume needed for an amount of 1000 ng of plasmid.
The volume of the restriction digest mix should be approx. 2.5× bigger than the plasmid volume. Calculate the ingredients as it can be seen in the table for the restriction digest reaction mix.
Prepare the restriction digest reaction mix by combining the ingredients in the calculated amounts and incubate for 1 h. The incubation temperature needs to be chosen according to the specific incubation temperature of the selected restriction enzyme.
Perform an agarose gel electrophoresis as described in step 2 by adding the appropriate amount of 6× loading dye and loading the whole reaction mix to the wells of the gel.
In case the correct restriction pattern appears on the gel the plasmid should be sent for sequencing with primers covering the overlapping part of the plasmid to the insert from both sides (see Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2966-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Agarose gel of the restriction digest of three pJK6.1 plasmids isolated from three different colonies using EcoRI
Expected is a pattern with signals at 3536 bp, 2257 bp, 1251 bp, and 177 bp. Clones 1 and 3 show the correct pattern (177 bp not shown due to low signal intensity). The Gibson assembly of these two plasmids was most likely successful and they can be sent for a final sequencing check.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2966_10.csv
Compare the sequence of the theoretical construct in SnapGene3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3] with the experimentally obtained sequence to verify the assembled plasmid.

Transform a mutation free and correctly assembled plasmid with competent E. coli Bap1(DarR)/pGro7 cells as described in step 4 (but using kanamycin and chloramphenicol) to create the production strain.
Create glycerol stocks of the Top10 and Bap1 strains for long-term storage at −80°C.
Inoculate 4 mL LB medium supplemented with kanamycin with the colony from the stored E. coli Top10 plate that possesses the correct plasmid. Likewise, inoculate 4 mL LB medium containing kanamycin and chloramphenicol with a colony of the E. coli Bap1/pGro7 strain created in step 7. Both cultures are prepared in 15 mL falcon tubes.
Incubate them overnight at 37°C and 180 rpm.
The next day take 600 μL from the culture and add them to a cryotube containing 600 µL sterile 50% glycerol.
Carefully mix by pipetting up and down and store the tube at −80°C.
Heterologous expression of the gene cluster
Timing: 7 days
In this section, the whole gene cluster of the natural product containing the gene of unknown function is expressed using the strain E. coli Bap1/pGro7/pJK6.1, whose construction is outlined in the section “strain construction[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.1]”.
Inoculate 4 mL LB medium supplemented with chloramphenicol and kanamycin with E. coli Bap1/pGro7/pJK6.1 in a 15 mL falcon tube and incubate it overnight at 37°C and 180 rpm.
On the following day inoculate 20 mL LB medium containing kanamycin and chloramphenicol with 1 mL of the overnight culture in a 100 mL flask. Incubate at 37°C and 180 rpm.
Incubate the cells until an OD600 value of 0.5 is reached, as described in the section preparation of electrocompetent E. coli Top10 and E. coli Bap1(DarR)/pGro7 cells[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.2].
Note: If the cells are overgrown, restart the experiment using 1 mL of the remaining overnight culture. An OD600 value in the range of 0.48 up to 0.6 is acceptable.

Induce the production by adding IPTG to the culture as well as KBr (materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]) and continue incubation for 3 days at 18°C and 180 rpm.
After 3 days of incubation take a sample and prepare it for LCMS measurement.
Take a 500 μL sample from the culture and centrifuge it at 15.000 × g for 4 min. The supernatant will be added to the tip column later, as described in step 13f.
During centrifugation prepare a stage tip column as it can be seen in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2966-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. C18 stage tip column set up
Heat a hex wrench with a Bunsen burner and use it to pierce a hole into the lid of a 2 mL Eppendorf tube.
Use a cannula to punch out two pieces (approx. 1 mm in diameter) of an Empore Octadecyl C18 47 mm extraction disk and push it into the tip of a pipette tip.
Note: When pushing the C18 sorbent into the tip, do not use too much force to pack the sorbent too tightly. The sorbent should fit into the tip, but must not be pushed deeply into it.
Equilibrate the column with 200 μL methanol by centrifugation at 3000 × g and 4°C for 4 min.
Remove the flowthrough and add 200 μL eluent 1 (5% acetonitrile with 0.1% formic acid, see also materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]).
Centrifugate for 4 min at 3000 × g and 4°C.
Discard the flowthrough and add 200 μL of the sample supernatant.
Centrifugate for 4 min at 3000 × g and 4°C.
Critical: Methanol is a flammable, toxic and hazardous substance. Methanol should be handled carefully with personal safety equipment and it should be handled and under the fume hood.

Note: The sample should pass through the column completely. If this is not the case after 4 min the centrifugation time can be increased. If prolonging the centrifugation time is not sufficient, the speed can be increased up to 4000 × g.
After the sample has passed through the column another 200 μL can be added and the centrifugation step is repeated.
Wash the column with 30 μL eluent 1 by centrifugation at 3000 × g and 4°C for 4 min.
Elute the column by adding 30 μL eluent 2 (20% acetonitrile with 0.1% formic acid, see also materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]).
Centrifugate for 4 min at 3000 × g and 4°C.
Repeat the elution step.
Transfer the sample to a LCMS vial, submit the sample to LCMS measurement and analyze the obtained data (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5], troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2966-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Extracted ion chromatogram (EIC, calc. [M + 2H]2+ ± 0.01 Da) and mass spectrum of bromodarobactin A (C47H54N11O12Br, 522.6641 m/z)
Left: Extracted ion chromatograms of bromodarobactin A of the control sample (pZW-ADC9, without darH, red) and of a pJK6.1 sample (blue). A peak is present in the pJK6.1 sample, but not in the control. Right: Mass spectrum of bromodarobactin A displaying the typical isotopic pattern of a brominated compound.
Critical: Eluent 1 and 2 should be handled with personal safety equipment and under the fume hood.
Heterologous expression of the His-tagged enzyme
Timing: 3 days
Inoculate 4 mL LB medium supplemented with chloramphenicol and kanamycin with E. coli Bap1/pGro7/pJK9.1 in a 15 mL falcon tube. Incubate overnight at 37°C and 180 rpm.
The next day inoculate 100 mL LB medium containing kanamycin and chloramphenicol with 1 mL of the overnight culture in a 300 mL flask. Incubate at 37°C and 180 rpm.

Incubate the cells until an OD600 value of 0.5 is reached as described in the section preparation of electrocompetent E. coli Top10 and E. coli Bap1(DarR)/pGro7 cells[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.2].
Note: If the cells are overgrown, restart the experiment using 1 mL of the remaining overnight culture. An OD600 value in the range of 0.48 up to 0.6 is acceptable.
Induce the production by adding IPTG (materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]) to the culture and continue incubation overnight at 18°C and 180 rpm.
The following steps have to be carried out on ice. Harvest the cells by centrifugation for 10 min at 10.000 × g and 4°C.
Decant the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 4 mL cool QIAGEN lysis buffer (materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]).
Pause point: Without lysis buffer the cell pellet can be stored at −20°C or −80°C for a few months.
Open the cells by sonication.
Sonicate for 35 s using the settings cycle 7 and 70%.
Pause for 35 s.
Repeat steps a and b three times.
Note: Cells can also be opened enzymatically.
Pellet the cell debris by centrifugation at 4°C and 10.000 × g for 30 min.
Pause point: The cleared supernatant can be store at −20°C for 2 weeks.
Optional: If the lysate was frozen, thaw it on ice.
Add 5 μL 4× NuPage LDS sample buffer to 20 μL of the cleared lysate obtained in step 21 and store the mixture at −20°C until it is used for SDS-PAGE analysis.
Purify the protein with a Ni-NTA column (QIAGEN).
Pipette 1 mL of the Ni-NTA slurry into a polypropylene column and drain the storage liquid.
Add the 4 mL of lysate obtained in step 21 on the column and let it slowly elute.

Take a 20 μL sample from the flowthrough, add 5 μL 4× NuPage LDS sample buffer and store the mixture at −20°C until it is used for SDS-PAGE analysis.
Wash the column twice with 2.5 mL of QIAGEN wash buffer (materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]).
Collect the washing fractions, mix 20 μL of each washing fraction with 5 μL 4× NuPage LDS sample buffer and store at −20°C until it is used for SDS-PAGE analysis.
Elute the column four times with 0.5 mL QIAGEN elution buffer (materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]).
Take a sample of 20 μL from each elution fraction and add 5 μL of 4× NuPage LDS sample buffer and store the mixture at −20°C until it is used for SDS-PAGE analysis.
Elution fractions should be stored with 10% glycerol.
Critical: Buffers for the protein purification contain imidazole and should be handled with personal safety equipment.
Pause point: SDS-PAGE samples can be stored at −20°C for weeks. Stability of the purified protein varies, but DarH is stable for at least 6 months at −20°C.
Perform an SDS-PAGE analysis of the samples collected during purification.
Take out a Mini-PROTEAN TGX Stain-Free gel from the package and remove the green tape form the bottom.
Assemble the Mini-PROTEAN tetra cell and add 1× running buffer (ROTIPHORESE 10× SDS-PAGE) into the inner and outer chamber.
Load the samples and the 10 μL of the PageRuler Prestained Protein Ladder into the wells of the gel and run the gel at 200 V until the dye reaches the bottom of the gel (approx. 30 min).
Use the opening lever at the marked positions to open the gel cassette.
Stain the gel with ROTIBlue staining solution.
Shake the staining solution.
Mix 10 mL ROTIBlue, 30 mL ddH2O, and 10 mL methanol in a 50 mL flacon tube.

Incubate the gel shaking in the staining solution for 2 h up to overnight.
If incubated overnight destain the gel in water for 2 h on the next day.
Use a camera to document the gel (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6], troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2966-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. SDS-PAGE gel of the His-tag purification of DarH using pJK9.1
Elution fractions 1,2, and 3 show a signal with the expected protein size of 58 kDa. Only faint signals of this size are visible in the washing fractions, which indicates that most of the product is bound to the column but it is nearly saturated. Elution fraction 2 can be used for an in vitro assay.
Critical: ROTIBlue, and methanol are hazardous substances and they should only be handled with personal safety equipment and under the fume hoot.
In vitro assay
Timing: 2 days
The in vitro halogenation assay is performed according to a modified protocol by Zehner et al.9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9] by preparing the halogenase in vitro assay mix and incubating it at 18°C for 24 h.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2966_11.csv
The reaction is stopped after incubation by adding an equal amount of methanol.
After centrifugation for 5 min at 15.000 × g the supernatant is transferred to a LCMS vial and subjected to LCMS measurement (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2966-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Extracted ion chromatogram (EIC, calc. [M + 2H]2+ ± 0.05 Da) of bromodarobactin A (C47H54N11O12Br, 522.6641 m/z, blue) and extracted ion chromatogram (EIC, calc. [M + 2H]2+ ± 0.05 Da) of darobactin A (C47H55N11O12, 483.7089 m/z, red)
After 24 h of incubation nearly all darobactin A (peak at approx. 3.5 min retention time, red) is converted to bromodarobactin A (peak at approx. 4.4 min retention time, blue).
Critical: Adding the methanol to stop the reaction should be performed with personal safety equipment and under the fume hood.
